instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3024: What is 820-3024? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.R7051: What is R7051? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7050: What is R7050? Current sense shunt resistor for the battery, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 17/18 on ISL6259 should give you 2.02 ohms. .
definitions.R7052: What is R7052? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7022: What is R7022? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuating. NSFW warning.
threads.message:
Board had a little corrosion; refer to attachment. :eek:
After an ultrasonic, some flux, another ultrasonic and a stint in the oven it turned on and chimed, then switched off.

Now it spins the fans for a second or two, then turns off for a second or two, then on, then off etc. Eventually it slows down to just twitching the fans every few moments.

@ J6900 DCIN fluctuates from 16.28 - 16.80.
F7030 goes from 13.9v to ~3v, then back up.

<CAPACITOR>C7200</CAPACITOR>::1 goes from 13.9v to about 3.6v and back again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuating. NSFW warning.
threads.message:
Resistance between pins 17/18 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, and pins 27/28 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>?

Is <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> steady?

And I bet <CHIP>U2700</CHIP> was corroded as well. 

This will likely be an issue around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. Battery current sensing, not charger current sensing, so my bet is on <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> & traces between them and the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuating. NSFW warning.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is stable.

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>::17/18 = OL
<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>::27/28 = 20ohms

<CHIP>U2700</CHIP> looked okay going by the photos I took.

<RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> is measuring almost 0ohms. (Whats the correct way to measure a current sensing resistor like this?)
<RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> is 3Mohm (nothing wrong there...)
<RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> is 0.1ohm

<RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> is obviously blown, but <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> looks pretty suspect too; will replace both and report back.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuating. NSFW warning.
threads.message:
Now I get no fan spin and F7040 is going as log as 1.8v.

Clearly I am on the right track, I can see now that it's cleaner a few traces are burnt / corroded away.

Will sort them next.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuating. NSFW warning.
threads.message: check value of <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR>, I suspect a bad ISL, what is resistance between pins 17/18 from ISL now??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuating. NSFW warning.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuating. NSFW warning.
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is getting really hot then it goes cools down for a second or two then gets hot again.

Should I replace it, or is this caused by an issue somewhere else?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuating. NSFW warning.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuating. NSFW warning.
threads.message:
OK will swap it out then.

I was wondering if it was trying to supply enough current to a capacitor that was shorting and giving up after a bit; then trying again.

Will swap it and report back.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuating. NSFW warning.
threads.message: Am I the only one wondering about why there is a NSFW warning in the title?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuating. NSFW warning.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dr. moast, post: 18778"]Am I the only one wondering about why there is a NSFW warning in the title?[/QUOTE]

Gore. Did you see the board?

Also a little bit of click bait factor.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuating. NSFW warning.
threads.message: Look at the diagram, the only way <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR> are ever going to go bad unless they are corroded off the board is if <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> dies and shorts to ground. Anytime those resistors are dead(and not just the traces around them) it's a surefire bet the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is bad as well.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuating. NSFW warning.
threads.message:
Thanks for the extra info.

I swapped <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, turned it on and something went SNAP, but I'm not sure what or where yet. :/

Might be too much wrong with this board after all...
